data.title: Is Dropbox (DBX) Now Attractively Priced After Recent Share Price Weakness?
data.description:
• Wondering whether Dropbox is a bargain or just fairly priced at its current level? This article walks through what the numbers are saying about the stock's value.
  • Dropbox shares last closed at US$24.43, with returns of a 1.2% decline over 7 days, 7.9% decline over 30 days, 9.3% decline year to date, 5.9% decline over 1 year, 18.2% over 3 years and 6.0% over 5 years, which may have some investors reassessing the balance between opportunity and risk.
  • Recent coverage around Dropbox has focused on its position as a mature cloud storage and collaboration platform and how investors weigh that against other software names. This helps frame the recent share price performance. Alongside that, ongoing discussion about competition in cloud services and productivity tools has kept attention on how much value the market is currently willing to assign to Dropbox.
  • On our framework, Dropbox scores a 5 out of 6 valuation score. This indicates it screens as undervalued on most of our checks. Next we will walk through the main valuation approaches we use, before finishing with a different way to look at value that can put all of these methods in context.

Dropbox delivered -5.9% returns over the last year. See how this stacks up to the rest of the Software industry.

Advertisement

Approach 1: Dropbox Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF model, looks at the cash Dropbox is expected to generate in the future and discounts those projections back to today, to estimate what the entire business could be worth right now.

For Dropbox, the model uses a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach based on cash flow projections. The latest twelve month free cash flow is about US$928.9 million. Analyst estimates and Simply Wall St extrapolations project free cash flow of roughly US$931.0 million in 2026 and US$1,296.6 million in 2035, with values between those years laid out in the ten year projection set.

When all those future cash flows are discounted back to today, the model arrives at an estimated intrinsic value of US$59.33 per share. Compared with the recent share price of US$24.43, the DCF output suggests the stock trades at a 58.8% discount, which points to Dropbox looking undervalued on this measure.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Dropbox is undervalued by 58.8%. Track this in your watchlist or portfolio, or discover 53 more high quality undervalued stocks.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Dropbox.

Approach 2: Dropbox Price vs Earnings (P/E)

For a profitable business like Dropbox, the P/E ratio is a useful shortcut because it links what you pay today directly to the earnings the company is already generating. In general, higher growth expectations and lower perceived risk tend to justify a higher P/E, while slower growth or higher risk usually point to a lower, more cautious multiple.

Dropbox currently trades on a P/E of 11.59x. That sits well below the Software industry average of 25.78x and also below the peer group average of 22.86x. To sharpen this comparison, Simply Wall St uses a proprietary ‚ÄúFair Ratio‚Äù of 20.38x, which is the P/E level the model suggests for Dropbox given factors such as its earnings profile, industry, profit margins, market cap and company specific risks.

This Fair Ratio is more tailored than a simple industry or peer comparison because it adjusts for Dropbox‚Äôs own characteristics instead of assuming it should trade exactly like the average software name. Setting the Fair Ratio of 20.38x against the actual 11.59x P/E implies the shares are pricing in a lower multiple than the model suggests might be appropriate.

Result: UNDERVALUED

P/E ratios tell one story, but what if the real opportunity lies elsewhere? Start investing in legacies, not executives. Discover our 21 top founder-led companies.

Upgrade Your Decision Making: Choose your Dropbox Narrative

Earlier we mentioned that there is an even better way to understand valuation. On Simply Wall St you can use Narratives on the Community page to attach your own story about Dropbox to a set of revenue, earnings and margin assumptions, link that story to a fair value, then compare it with the current price to help decide whether you see Dropbox as closer to the higher US$30 or lower US$20 fair value cases. The Narrative automatically updates as new news or earnings arrive so your view stays connected to the latest information rather than a static spreadsheet.

For Dropbox, here are previews of two leading Dropbox narratives:

üêÇ Dropbox Bull Case

Fair value in this bullish narrative: US$30.00 per share

Implied discount to this fair value: 18.6% below the narrative fair value at the recent US$24.43 share price

Revenue trend used in this narrative: 29.8% annual decline

  • Assumes Dropbox successfully leans into AI led products like Dash and workflow tools for enterprises, supporting higher margins and long term cash generation.
  • Builds in an expectation that share buybacks reduce the share count meaningfully, which supports earnings per share even with a soft revenue trend.
  • Identifies long term potential if management can keep investing in AI tools while holding on to profitability, with churn, competition and a shrinking paid user base as key risks.

üêª Dropbox Bear Case

Fair value in this bearish narrative: US$20.00 per share

Implied premium to this fair value: 22.2% above the narrative fair value at the recent US$24.43 share price

Revenue trend used in this narrative: 157.2% annual decline

  • Assumes elevated churn in Teams customers, reduced investment in non core lines and headwinds in outbound sales that keep pressure on revenue and earnings.
  • Treats the shift from mature file storage into AI tools like Dash as a source of execution uncertainty, with slower contribution from new products and sensitivity to currency moves.
  • Views the current price as demanding, based on a fair value anchor of US$20.00 that already factors in profitability, buybacks and some benefit from AI, while still highlighting competition and growth risk.

These two narratives bracket the recent share price by using different assumptions about revenue trends, margins and how much credit Dropbox earns for its AI initiatives and capital returns. The useful next step is to decide which set of assumptions feels closer to how you see the business, or to shape your own view somewhere between the two.

data.title: McDonald's (MCD) Margin Steadiness Tested By Premium Valuation After FY 2025 Results
data.description:
McDonald's (MCD) closed out FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of US$7.0 billion and basic EPS of US$3.03, alongside net income of US$2,164 million, setting the tone for a year where trailing 12 month revenue reached US$26.9 billion and EPS came in at US$12.00. Over the past few quarters, revenue has moved from US$5,956 million in Q1 2025 to US$7,078 million in Q3 2025 before landing at US$7,009 million in Q4. Quarterly EPS ranged between US$2.61 and just over US$3.19, with a trailing net profit margin of 31.9%.

See our full analysis for McDonald's.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings profile lines up against the widely held narratives around McDonald's growth, income appeal, and long term resilience.

See what the community is saying about McDonald's

Advertisement

31.9% net margin supports quality story

  • Over the last 12 months, McDonald's converted US$26.9b of revenue into US$8.6b of net income, for a 31.9% net margin that sits slightly above last year's 31.7%.
  • Consensus narrative expects tech investments, an asset light model, and international expansion to support strong margins. The current 31.9% margin alongside trailing EPS of US$12.00 gives some backing to that bullish view, even as:
    • Same restaurant sales growth in 2025 swung from a 1% decline in Q1 to positive growth of 3.8% and 3.6% in Q2 and Q3, showing mixed traffic trends beneath the margin stability.
    • Net income over the last four quarters moved in a relatively tight range between US$1.9b and US$2.3b, which fits the idea of steady earnings but not rapid acceleration.

McDonald's Future Earnings Per Share Growth

Store base tops 44,000 with mixed traffic

  • Total restaurants increased from 43,756 in Q1 2025 to 44,599 by Q3 2025, while same restaurant sales growth moved from a 1% decline in Q1 to gains of 3.8% in Q2 and 3.6% in Q3.
  • Bears highlight the risk that declining low income traffic and market saturation could pressure U.S. revenues. The swing from a 1.5% decline in same restaurant sales in Q3 2024 to positive mid single digit growth in 2025 supports the idea that traffic is not uniformly weak, even as:
    • The reliance on higher same restaurant sales growth to support future earnings means any renewed traffic softness could limit how much benefit McDonald's gets from its larger 44,000 plus store base.
    • Concerns about market saturation and franchisee economics remain relevant, because unit growth from 42,819 restaurants in Q3 2024 to 44,599 in Q3 2025 needs to be matched by healthy guest counts to sustain systemwide sales.

Critics who focus on traffic risk may want to see how that concern stacks up against the numbers in the dedicated bear case for McDonald's, which digs into same restaurant sales trends, cost pressures, and unit growth assumptions. üêª McDonald's Bear Case

Premium valuation above DCF fair value

  • At a share price of US$333.01, McDonald's trades at a trailing P/E of 27.6x versus the US Hospitality industry average of 23.2x, sits below the peer average of 55.8x, and is above a DCF fair value estimate of about US$242.21.
  • Supportive investors point to 5 year annual earnings growth of 8.3% and forecast earnings growth of roughly 6.8% per year. Those figures, combined with a 2.23% dividend yield and a 31.9% net margin, heavily support the bullish case that a premium P/E can be justified, even as:
    • The gap between the current share price of US$333.01 and the DCF fair value of about US$242.21 underlines the risk that some buyers are paying above modeled cash flow value.
    • Forecast revenue growth of about 5.1% per year is not especially high, so a 27.6x P/E relies on confidence that margins and earnings growth near 6.8% can be maintained.

If you're trying to decide whether that premium price tag fits with your own expectations for growth and cash generation, it can help to see how bullish investors frame the long term story around digital, margins, and capital returns in one place. üêÇ McDonald's Bull Case

data.title: Is Coupang (CPNG) Pricing Reflect Its South Korean E Commerce Strength After Recent Share Pullback
data.description:
• If you are wondering whether Coupang's current share price really reflects what the business is worth, this article will walk through what the numbers are saying about value.
  • The stock last closed at US$18.36, with returns of 1.7% over 7 days, a 6.2% decline over 30 days, a 21.4% decline year to date, and a 26.6% decline over 1 year. The 3 year return sits at 25.2%.
  • Recent coverage has focused on Coupang's position in the South Korean e commerce market and how its scale and logistics network fit into long term expectations for online retail. This context has shaped how investors interpret the recent share price moves and the balance between growth potential and risk.
  • On our checks, Coupang scores a 2 out of 6 valuation score, which raises some important questions about how it stacks up on different methods. We will look at those approaches next, then finish with a framework that can help you assess value more completely.

Coupang scores just 2/6 on our valuation checks. See what other red flags we found in the full valuation breakdown.

Advertisement

Approach 1: Coupang Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model takes estimates of a company‚Äôs future cash flows and discounts them back to today using a required rate of return, to arrive at an estimate of what the business might be worth right now.

For Coupang, the model uses a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach based on cash flow projections. The latest twelve month Free Cash Flow is about $1.27b. Analysts provide explicit Free Cash Flow estimates for the earlier years, and Simply Wall St then extrapolates further out, with projected Free Cash Flow of $2.89b in 2030. Each of these future cash flows is discounted back to today and added together.

On this basis, the DCF output suggests an estimated intrinsic value of US$28.51 per share, compared with the recent share price of US$18.36. That gap implies the stock is 35.6% undervalued according to this model. This indicates a meaningful margin between price and estimated value.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Coupang is undervalued by 35.6%. Track this in your watchlist or portfolio, or discover 53 more high quality undervalued stocks.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Coupang.

Approach 2: Coupang Price vs Earnings

For profitable companies, the P/E ratio is a useful way to relate what you pay per share to the earnings the business is currently generating. It gives you a quick sense of how many dollars investors are willing to pay today for one dollar of current earnings.

What counts as a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù P/E really depends on how the market views a company‚Äôs growth potential and risk. Higher expected growth or lower perceived risk can justify a higher P/E, while lower growth expectations or higher risk usually point to a lower P/E being reasonable.

Coupang is trading on a P/E of 86x. That is well above the Multiline Retail industry average of 19.65x and also above the peer average of 28.99x. Simply Wall St‚Äôs Fair Ratio for Coupang, which is 36.15x, estimates what P/E might be appropriate after considering factors like earnings growth, industry, profit margins, market cap and specific risks.

This Fair Ratio can be more informative than a simple comparison to peers or the industry because it adjusts for those company specific drivers instead of assuming one size fits all. With Coupang‚Äôs actual P/E of 86x versus the Fair Ratio of 36.15x, the shares screen as expensive on this metric.

Result: OVERVALUED

• Uber Technologies (NYSE:UBER) is rolling out Uber Air powered by Joby, bringing electric air taxis into its platform as a new aerial ride hailing option.
  • The company is acquiring parking platform SpotHero to let users reserve parking directly within the Uber app.
  • Uber is also formally launching Uber Autonomous Solutions to support and scale robotaxi deployments across global markets.

For you as an investor, these moves show how Uber is pushing beyond its core ridesharing and food delivery services into a broader mobility platform that spans ground, air and autonomous transport. Electric air taxis, app based parking and driverless rides all sit within major industry themes around electrification, automation and integrated trip planning. NYSE:UBER is positioning itself at several of those junctions at once.

data.title: Corcept Therapeutics (CORT) Margin Compression Reinforces Bearish Narrative Despite FY 2025 Revenue Strength
data.description:

Corcept Therapeutics FY 2025 earnings snapshot

Corcept Therapeutics (CORT) has wrapped up FY 2025 with Q4 revenue of US$202.1 million and basic EPS of US$0.24, alongside net income of US$25.4 million. Over the past six quarters, the company has seen revenue move from US$181.9 million in Q4 2024 to a range between US$157.2 million and US$207.6 million per quarter, while basic EPS has ranged between US$0.19 and US$0.45. Margins Under Pressure As Net Profit Slides To US$99.7 Million

  • On a trailing 12 month basis, net income is US$99.7 million on US$761.4 million of revenue, which lines up with the 13.1% net margin mentioned earlier compared with 20.7% a year ago.
  • Bears point to this margin compression as a key risk, and the recent numbers back up part of that concern:
    • Net income over the last 12 months, at US$99.7 million, is below the US$139.7 million level a year earlier, even though trailing revenue increased from US$675.0 million to US$761.4 million.
    • This mix of higher sales and lower profitability fits the bearish argument that rising R&D and SG&A to support the pipeline and commercial build out could keep net margins under pressure.

Skeptics warn that if costs keep climbing faster than revenue, future approvals may not translate cleanly into stronger bottom line results. üêª Corcept Therapeutics Bear Case

Revenue Near US$761 Million Backs High-Growth Story

  • Trailing 12 month revenue has reached US$761.4 million, up from US$628.6 million six quarters ago, and is characterized as growing around 21% annually, faster than the broader US market rate of 10.4% cited in the analysis.
  • Supporters of the bullish view argue that this revenue base, combined with the pipeline, sets up strong earnings expansion:
    • Trailing EPS of US$0.96 per share sits on that higher revenue level, and analysts are cited as expecting earnings to grow around 44.7% per year from here.
    • Bulls tie that growth outlook to potential new indications in hypercortisolism and oncology, suggesting that today‚Äôs revenue run rate may be only a starting point if key trials and approvals play out as they expect.

Bulls argue that if Corcept can convert its late stage pipeline into approved products, the current revenue base could look conservative in hindsight. üêÇ Corcept Therapeutics Bull Case

Premium 38.7x P/E Versus DCF Fair Value Of About US$325

  • The shares trade at a trailing P/E of 38.7x on a price of US$36.22, above both the peer average of 34.8x and the US Pharmaceuticals industry average of 19.9x, while an internal DCF fair value estimate sits much higher at about US$324.99.
  • This combination creates a split between bulls and bears on valuation:
    • Critics highlight the premium P/E against industry and peers as a sign that a lot of the future growth story is already reflected in the multiple, especially with trailing net margin at 13.1% versus 20.7% a year ago.
    • Supporters point to the large gap between the current share price of US$36.22 and the cited DCF fair value near US$325 as evidence that the market is not fully reflecting the forecast earnings growth and pipeline potential.

Approach 1: MACOM Technology Solutions Holdings Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model estimates what a company could be worth by projecting its future cash flows and discounting them back to today using a required return. It focuses on the cash the business may generate for shareholders rather than accounting earnings.

For MACOM Technology Solutions Holdings, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach. The company‚Äôs latest twelve month free cash flow is about $151.8 million. Analysts provide explicit free cash flow estimates out to 2028, with Simply Wall St extrapolating further figures out to 2035, including a projected free cash flow of $945.6 million in 2035.

When all those projected cash flows are discounted back to today, the DCF model produces an estimated intrinsic value of about $114.39 per share. Compared with the current share price of around $253.37, this output suggests the stock is 121.5% above this particular estimate of intrinsic value based on the model‚Äôs cash flow scenario.

Result: OVERVALUED

Approach 2: MACOM Technology Solutions Holdings Price vs Earnings

For profitable companies, the P/E ratio is a useful way to think about value because it links what you pay per share to the earnings the business is currently generating. A higher P/E can reflect stronger expected growth or lower perceived risk, while a lower P/E can point to more muted growth expectations or higher uncertainty.

MACOM Technology Solutions Holdings is trading on a P/E of 117.26x. That sits well above the Semiconductor industry average of 44.48x and also above the peer average of 39.25x. On the surface, that kind of gap suggests investors are paying a much higher price for each dollar of earnings than is typical for the sector or for similar companies.

Because it looks at company specific drivers as well as its sector and market cap, it aims to be a more rounded guide to what might be considered a balanced valuation range.

Comparing the current P/E of 117.26x with the Fair Ratio of 38.30x points to MACOM trading well above that model based assessment.
